timeline.body:
Is there a brief period when isExpired() is false even though the original certificate did expire?
Server gives expiration timestamp as `SERVER_TIME + expiresAt`.
Client gets a response at `SERVER_TIME + LATENCY` and sets its `this.expires` to `SERVER_TIME + LATENCY + expiresAt * 1000`.
expiresAt milliseconds pass; server rotates certificates. Authentication requests fail because of the mismatch, but `refresh()` bails out immediately because LATENCY has not passed yet, and `isExpired()` still returns false.

In real life it would be a negligibly small time period, but it could be longer if the original certificate fetch stalled.

timeline.body: Could [NimbusJwtDecoder](https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/blob/05caf3d8fbdba89f42de621c04dce454317431e8/oauth2/oauth2-jose/src/main/java/org/springframework/security/oauth2/jwt/NimbusJwtDecoder.java#L183) be more helpful here? Nimbus has some re-downloading and an [expiring cache](https://javadoc.io/doc/com.nimbusds/nimbus-jose-jwt/latest/com/nimbusds/jose/jwk/source/DefaultJWKSetCache.html) implementation.
timeline.bodyText: Could NimbusJwtDecoder be more helpful here? Nimbus has some re-downloading and an expiring cache implementation.

timeline.author: elefeint

replies.bodyText: It won't work, because that is for JWKSet spec, and Firebase does not follow that json standard. It only outputs a dictionary with the key_id :  PEMString, so the decoder would fail. That's one of the reasons I implemented all from scratch. I have also considered using HttpCachingClient from Apache HttpClient, but it would be able to cache the resource, but the parsing of the certificate would still happen for every token invocation, so I decided to cache the whole operation.
